intro: Bouchea incisa, commonly known as the desert broom, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-like fruits. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its flowers are usually yellow or orange, appearing in clusters and attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Bouchea incisa is often used in xeriscaping due to its low water requirements and ornamental value.
